channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Dozens of Militants Killed in Pakistan in Wake of Taliban Attack on School
item.description: Pakistani forces stepped up operations against insurgents near the Afghan border after 148 students and staff members died in a siege in Peshawar.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Chinese Court Sides With Gay Man Against Clinic That Tried to ‘Convert’ Him
item.description: A court in Beijing ruled that the clinic must pay compensation to a gay man who sued it for giving him electric shocks intended to change his sexual orientation.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN

item.title: Obama Vows U.S. Response to North Korea Cyberattack on Sony
item.description: President Obama said the U.S. “will respond proportionally,” and he criticized Sony Pictures for giving in to intimidation and pulling the satirical movie that provoked the attacks.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: The headquarters of Sony Pictures in Culver City, Calif. The F.B.I. said that some of the methods employed in the Sony cyberattack were similar to ones that were used by the North Koreans against South Korean banks.

item.title: America Resurgent, Obama Tells Reporters
item.description: “We are better positioned than we have been in a very long time,” President Obama said Friday in a news conference after a period of extraordinary domestic and foreign policy changes.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Israeli Army Still Poses Obstacles for Women
item.description: Israel is the only nation with a gender-neutral draft, but that may sound more equal than it is, as one woman who made it near the top learned.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maj. Gen. Orna Barbivai reached the highest ranks of the Israeli Army. After 34 years in the service, she retired in the fall.

item.title: FIFA to Release Redacted Report on Corruption in World Cup Bidding
item.description: Sepp Blatter, the president of the world governing body of soccer, said the findings by an ethics committee would be edited to protect privacy and investigations.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Sepp Blatter, speaking on Friday after a meeting of FIFA’s executive committee, said, “We have always been determined that the truth should be known.”

item.title: Sinking Oil Price Is Hard on North Sea Producers
item.description: The price plunge is forcing oil producers everywhere to recalibrate. But the high costs of Britain’s industry make it particularly vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED
item.media:description: A BP oil platform in the North Sea, about 100 miles east of Aberdeen.

item.title: China Protests Planned U.S. Sale of Warships to Taiwan
item.description: A Foreign Affairs Ministry spokesman said President Obama’s approval of the transfer of four used frigates “brutally interferes in China’s domestic affairs.”
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Investigating Murder Claims, London Police Bolster Rumors of Pedophile Ring
item.description: Detectives have reinforced suspicion of sex abuse among prominent Britons in the 1970s and 1980s after questioning a man who says he was victimized as a boy.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Lithuania Assembles a Force as it Readies for Whatever Russia May Bring
item.description: In the first of its kind along NATO’s eastern flank, Lithuania’s rapid-reaction force was formed in an effort to avoid against Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: The road toward the training field at Rukla military base in Lithuania. Lithuania created a 2,500-member rapid-reaction force, to respond to possible threats from Russia.

item.title: Scientist Who Had Claimed Stem Cell Breakthrough Resigns From Japanese Research Institute
item.description: The institute said the researcher had failed in the three months it gave her to replicate what she had portrayed as a simple way to make stem cells.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Cuba Thaw Lets Rest of Latin America Warm to Washington
item.description: Leaders who have consistently lambasted the United States and President Obama abruptly changed course, praising the policy shift on Cuba.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Mandy Rice-Davies, Figure in Britain’s Profumo Affair, Dies at 70
item.description: Ms. Rice-Davies achieved notoriety in 1963 in one of Britain’s most spectacular sex scandals, which brought down a cabinet minister.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Mandy Rice-Davies leaving court in 1963 after testifying for the prosecution against Stephen Ward, who also played a role in Profumo scandal. Ms. Rice-Davies has died at age 70.

item.title: 8 Australian Children Are Found Dead in House
item.description: Their bodies were discovered in Manoora, a suburb of Cairns, and a woman believed to be the mother of seven of them was seriously injured.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Russia to Seek 10-Year Sentence for Putin Critic
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, a prominent opposition figure, and his brother, Oleg, were accused of stealing almost $500,000 from two firms.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Ex-City Official and Property Tycoon Are Convicted in Hong Kong Graft Trial
item.description: The trial suggested the cozy ties between the city’s business elite and career officials who rose through the ranks of the British colonial government.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Under Xi, China’s Wave of ‘Weird Architecture’ May Have Peaked
item.description: Ever since President Xi Jinping issued his admonishment against the rise of outlandish and exorbitant buildings across China, government officials, planners and architects have been scrambling to figure out what it means for them.
item.dc:creator: By CAO LI
item.media:description: An artist's rendition of the Chaoyang Park Plaza development, left, which developers have warned may be the last oddly shaped buildings constructed in Beijing for some time.

item.title: 8 Children Found Stabbed to Death in Australia
item.description: Their bodies were discovered in a house in Manoora, a suburb of Cairns, and a woman believed to be their mother was seriously injured.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Outside a house located in a suburb of Cairns, where the bodies of eight children were found.

item.title: Pakistani Forces Kill 59 Militants Near Afghan Border
item.description: Pakistani jets and ground forces killed 59 militants in a northwestern tribal region near the Afghan border, the army said Friday, days after Taliban fighters killed 148 people in a school massacre.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: South Korea Disbands Party Sympathetic to North
item.description: The court ruling against the United Progressive Party marked a political victory for President Park Geun-hye, who had sought to have the party dissolved.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
